text:
I grew up knowing that a
lot of people in my family

didn't graduate from high
school, let alone college.

And as I got older,
what I realized

was education was going to be
the tool for which I can not

only lift up myself, but lift
up the community and my family,

these people who love
me and who raised me.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I was born and raised
in New Orleans.

My dad really
helped us understand

what it meant, as a black
man, to love yourself.

I remember stories of
saying, I love myself.

He would make us
say it three times
in the morning before school.

My mom, she dedicated
so much of her time

to us, to me and my brothers,
raising three black boys,

given all that our
family had been through.

We are sort of all
connected in this journey,

and it takes our courage
to be able to look

into those people
and those experiences

that which we belong to and
drive forward with all of that.

I don't get to this place and I
don't become Class Day speaker

without hundreds of people who
took the time, who sacrificed,

who poured into me, and
I believed them and I
went forth because of that.

And it's important for
young people to know that.

Going to Yale from where I
came from was just a blessing.

Being able to teach felt
like a blessing to me.

And this was really
because growing up

at the same high school,
what I saw day in

and day out was students,
my classmates, my friends,

who often had the
potential to do better

but they just never had
someone to help them
connect the dots with them.

And this is why going back to
teach was so important to me.

It was, can I be the person
who helps to connect the dots?

And then I worked in
economic development,

where I started to
understand and I

started to see just how
communities developed
and how economies developed.

What you learn over time, is
that a lot of these decisions

were being made in
the private sector.

I often told myself, I want
to be in those conversations.

But there was a gap
between where I was
and where I needed to be.

And so I applied to
Harvard Business School.

I wanted to be pushed, and what
better way than the case method
to do that?

What I know for sure
that I learned here
is that my voice matters.

My name is Brandon Rapp, I
am graduating Class of 2019
at Harvard Business School.
